Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2010 05:07PM loligag wrote: I chose to have a lumpectomy and had it done at Stanford. I read a lot of studies leaning towards it being of benefit. It made me feel better knowing the tumor load was diminished. They did not touch my lymph nodes as it is of no benefit to us Stage IV ladies to have them removed. The surgery was only an hour and I had wire guides inserted beforehand. That was the worst part. I had zero pain after surgery and was released the same day.  I was Stage IV at initial diagnosis on 7/29/09 and had the surgery 3/17/10. They were able to get clear margins, which is key for the surgery to be of benefit to Stage IV.  I'm back on chemo and will probably have radiation after a couple of treatments. This will depend on the status of my liver mets. There's no rush for the radiation. The mets are more important being treated systemically at this time.   From my limited understanding, the breast tumor can still send out daughter cells to other parts of the body. By removing the primary tumor, it prevents this from happening.  I have an appointment at the Block Center near Chicago next Tues and will ask them about this. They seem to be in tune with latest research.

Posts.Title: NEVER thought it would happen.. I have a boyfriend!! JeninMichigan seaperch

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2011 11:12PM loligag wrote: I haven't been on Xeloda, but Taxotere caused edema all over, especially in my kegs. I looked like I had elephant legs. Lasiks didn't work. I got relief from seeing a lympheda therapist who gave me lymphatic massages. She also wrapped my legs with bandages every day for 2 weeks to get the swelling down. I still have it a little and have been off Taxotere for a year. I have to do daily exercises and wear support stockings. What also helped was having surgery (lumpectomy) in the midst of it. The fluids pumped through me during surgery got rid of a lot of the water retention. I lost 28lbs in 14 days. Don't let your Oncologist ignore it. Mine was slow to react. It can be miserable. I lost a lot of strength in my legs. Hope this helped.

I have 2 aunts who overcame breast and colon cancer. One is still alive at 88 and the other passed away at 84. I have old age envy. I don't have kids but can only imagine it makes it so much harder dealing with this wretched disease. Blessings to all.

Posts.Title: Husband had emotional affair Goodwife1 susan_02143

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2010 03:56PM loligag wrote: Hi Flachica, my liver mets do the same as yours and after 6 treatments they are dramatically improved. I'm ER-/PR- and Her 2+ and am on Herceptin and Taxotere. I also had pain at the biopsy site. I've had 2 scans and the second was way better than the first. I didn't have any SE's until treatment #5, when I started getting edema (swelling in the feet and lower legs). This is a known SE of Taxotere. Symptoms can be relieved by diuretics, elevation and support hose. My tear ducts also blocked up, causing me to have teary eyes all the time. I am scheduled to have stents installed in March. If this happens to you, don't wait to have this done as the ducts can get too hard and closed up. Don't got to an Opthamologist. I wasted time going to one. You need to see an Ocular Plastics specialist. Taxotere can be tough on some, but it's worth it.  Do whatever you can for stress and scanxiety control. If you can swing it get massages. I also listen to a lot of relaxation and visual imagery tapes. A great website to get these is www.healthjourneys.com.    A great documentary video that you might be able to identify with because the heroine is about your age is Crazy Sexy Cancer by Kris Carr. She also has a couple of books out. She has liver mets that make her liver resemble swiss cheese.   Anyway, this may be more info than you were looking for, but it comes with hugs and blessings.  Edwina
Posts.Title: Newly dx’ed w/liver mets – question about drugs and ab pain flachica Melanie36

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 12:15AM loligag wrote: I feel like we're the relations in the basement no-one wants to talk about. I can't stand the sight of pink, and I don't look good in  it either. I look much better than I feel and am always putting on a front. People don't really want to hear the truth. Before I was diagnosed, at least I knew Stage IV of any cancer was terminal. It's unbelievable how little people know about the high death rate for stage IV BC. Someone said to me they know a survivor of stage V or VI, they couldn't recall, but that person is fine now. In the news it doesn't help when Michael Douglas' doctors declare his stage IV cancer is 80% curable. I wish that were true of BC. Now people are going to think all cancers are  80% curable at stage IV. Can't win Love and hugs to all you wonderful ladies.

I talked to my onco about it and he was reluctant to put a timeframe on my life expectancy. One policy specifies 6 months and the other 12 months. How long did it take?
Posts.Title: Accelerated benefits - Have you considered withdrawing? JennGrace vickib

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2010 04:03PM loligag wrote: Thank you Ladies! I would never have thought of doing this. I cashed in 2 policies and am soon to be mortgage free and financial worry free. The process was a lot easier than I imagined. I filled out my section, had the Onc fill out his, mailed it in and 3 weeks later the checks were in my hand. We're giving 10% to charity, paying off the mortgage and doing a little remodeling to the house. I paid no attention to the life expectancy. It's just a number.  The joy of receiving those checks far surpassed any down side. I think the joy I felt actually added years to my life I'm more of a lurker than a contributor as I can't top most of the replies. But, I LOVE this site and it's helped me a lot. Hardly a day goes by that I don't check the posts.

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2012 07:42AM loligag wrote: I talked to my onco about SIRT and he recommended chemoembolization over it as he said it works better on Her2, which mine is. After the recent mastectomy I had, I now only have evidence of mets in my liver. So, if this works, I finally have a shot at being NED! Because I have mets in 2 lobes, it will take 2 procedures. I'm currently waiting to be scheduled, but the first procedure should be within the next 2 weeks. I'm having a CT scan on Mon just in case mets have popped up anywhere else. Once that is done, things will be set in motion. So, wish me luck!

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 02:42PM loligag wrote: I had a lumpectomy with clear margins in March of this year after 7 herceptin/taxotere treatments which shrunk the breast tumor from 6 cm to 2 cm and dramatically reduced my liver mets. My onco had no opinion, but the breast surgeon at Stanford recommended it and I agreed after researching it. Also, I just felt better not having it there anymore. I had no node removal as it's not therapeutic with Stage IV. All we would gain from it is lymphedema. Last week I went to the now famous Block Center in Evanston, IL and the oncologist agreed with the lumpectomy. He said the primary continues to send out cancer cells.

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2012 11:50AM loligag wrote: I'm on 1500 mg twice a day too. I started with two weeks on and one week off, but because I had severe side effects onc is switching me to 1 week on and one week off. I didn't have any SE's until week 2 of cycle 2, but then all hell broke loose. I had nausea, fatigue, H/F syndrome, severe diarrhea. I'm on a 2 week break right now before starting the new Xeloda schedule. I continue to take Tykerb every day. I haven't had a scan yet since starting, but I hear it has a high success rate. SE's have improved greatly in the week since I stopped. I found though, that coconut is great for stopping diarrhea. All forms work - coconut juice, water, milk or macaroons.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 08:01PM loligag wrote: Have you been on Herceptin? I'm surprised your Onc didn't switch you when you couldn't take Tykerb. The comparison protocol to TDM-1 is Tykerb/Xeloda. I was on TDM-1 for 5 months and the wash out period was one cycle, which was 3 weeks. I was on Herceptin alone at the time. Don't worry needlessly about it. You're on Xeloda, so you're covered. You're not jeopardizing your life. Good luck with the trial.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 07:14PM loligag wrote: I follow an organic, no dairy, low fat, no sugar, no meat diet with a daily load of supplements that make me want to gag when I think about it,. most of the time. I also exercise 30 minutres a day. I do it mostly to keep in general good health. I don't want to be fightuing heart disease or diabetes AND cancer. One disease at a time, please. Having said that, I've been off chemo but on herceptin only, since July and my WBC was not recovering. This past week before my herceptin infusion yesterday, we went to San Francisco for a few days and I ate and drank (wine) with abandon. Ate meat, fried food, dessert. Low and behold, my WBC shot up and is back to normal. I do drink wine regularly, a guilty pleasure I refuse to give up. I think the stress of abstaining would shorten my life even more. I drink 2-3 , 60z glasses 3-4 times a week. I try not to drink 2 days in a row. I heard that regular drinkers before treatment do better than non-drinkers as our livers are used to flushing out toxins

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 12:32PM - edited Mar 3, 2010 12:35PM by loligag Hi 3katz, I'm an HR Manager and have been for 20 years  Although the comment violated HIPAA and ADA  I've seen a lot worse. If there's a comment section on the review for you to fill out, you could put something there to the effect that the reference to your medical condition is irrelevant. Don't be too inflammatory in your statement. If you feel comfortable, you could mention it directly to the supervisor who wrote it so he/she can keep it off subsequent reviews. Sounds like it was well intentioned, albeit illegal. Most supervisors aren't aware comments like that are illegal. I guess what it boils down to is, is it worth making a stink over, considering the review is favorable. I think, however, that it is worth handling informally with your supervisor.  You could request your review be rewritten without that comment. If you don't nip it in the bud, it could spill over into other areas. If I was the HR Manager there I would advise the supervisor to change it and  apologize to you, unless they want a plaintiff lawyer with a laundry list of employment law violations come raining down on him/her. Not to stir the pot, but are you sure no-one got a raise? If you were the only one who didn't due to the "bad economy", heaven help your employer.
Posts.Title: Review @ work - was this professional?Or called for? 3katz rayofsun

Posts.Content: May 21, 2011 03:08PM loligag wrote: I say keep working if you want to. I worked for a year after diagnosis and finally quit as it became overwhelming. Luckily, I have a LTD program through work. They deduct for SSDI, but I can work a few hours a week which helps me feel normal. I couldn't keep on top of my game working full time. Between SSDI, LTD and part-time work, I'm not losing much income. My hubby carries the insurance. Best of luck to you.
